awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Adaptable Refrigeration Cycles for Smart Mini-Containers
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this SBIR Phase I project includes reductions in food waste, energy use, and carbon emissions by developing a highly efficient and adaptable system for refrigerated transport. Mini-containers, which are small, insulated boxes with environments controlled by a central driving unit that contains a refrigerator and other environmental controls are proposed. The technology may increase the economic feasibility of small farms by allowing them to target a more resilient, efficient, and potentially carbon-neutral cold supply chain. The potential impact of the research includes improved availability of nutritious food for the general population and mitigation of negative environmental effects of cold logistics. Additionally, mitigating food waste will create savings up and down the supply chain.

Two key technical challenges are addressed in this research. The first area has, as its main objective, the development of a volume-adaptable refrigeration system that allows for the efficient operation of several levels of control to best adapt to high levels of cooling capacity needs. The second area of research corresponds to the development of the methodology and solutions algorithms to exercise a hybrid control strategy for the optimal scheduling operation of the refrigeration system. The archetype refrigeration system would be subject to constraints imposed by the heterogeneous loads stored in the different special storage and transportation units known as mini-containers which receive cooling and other environmental services.  This technology will allow for efficiently aggregating, storing, disaggregating, and distributing fresh products in the mini-containers. The mini-containers will allow the emergence of efficient cold logistics for small loads by enabling the capacity of large transportation containers to be split among multiple conveyances. The proposed solution will also make it possible to convert almost any truck into a refrigerated truck and any warehouse into a cold storage facility, supporting the emergence of sharing economies in cold logistics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of Phase I was to demonstrate the feasibility of developing a highly efficient, adaptive refrigeration system for environmental conditioning of varied and dynamic loads. The system is designed for a transportation and cold storage solution using mini-containers - 4x4x4 ft³, stackable, insulated, and environmentally controlled boxes. These cyber-enabled, modular units can be connected incrementally, enabling shared capacity among multiple shipments with diverse products, environments, shippers, sources, and destinations. This innovative approach offers unprecedented flexibility and efficiency in logistics and cold supply chain management.

Since the mini-containers do not have their own refrigeration system, they are connected to another mini-container containing what is termed as the “Central Driving Unit” (CDU), housing refrigeration, purification, and communications and control systems. The combination of mini-containers with the an efficient refrigeration system reduces logistics costs, food waste and energy/emissions footprint from perishable products.

One of the key design objectives for the Central Driving Unit (CDU) is to operate solely on battery power, enabling the utilization of renewable energy sources and thereby significantly reducing greenhouse gas emissions. This presents significant development challenges for the envisioned system, particularly in creating a refrigeration system that can efficiently operate across a wide range of cooling loads.

In order to address the technical challenges represented by the desired design features as part of this SBIR grant the following objectives were set: “the development of a low-cost refrigeration system that optimally adapts to highly variable cooling loads. To reach this objective it is necessary to tackle several challenging technical issues, salient among them are 1) the design, analysis and synthesis of a fully controllable adaptive variable-refrigerant system that minimizes energy use while observing the constraints imposed by refrigeration load, and 2) the development of a hybrid scheduling and control system based on prescriptive analytics.”

To achieve the previous objectives, hypotheses were formulated and validated using a combination of theoretical and experimental approaches. To collect relevant data for hypothesis testing, a custom testbed was designed (see attached figure) and constructed to simulate the operation of a refrigeration system capable of adapting to highly variable cooling loads.

The testbed data corroborated the core concept that refrigeration system settings must be dynamically adjusted in response to fluctuating cooling demands from the CDU. The findings revealed that using suboptimal settings or cooling capacities can lead to substantial energy waste. For instance, the attached graph shows the estimated energy consumed at different combinations of level of refrigerant mass and targeted temperature.

Moreover, the results demonstrated that operating the CDU under various setting and environmental condition combinations alters the key drivers of energy consumption, highlighting the complexity of optimizing energy efficiency.

While the previous experimental results assumed steady-state conditions, real-world applications often involve transient states. To address this, a new set of experiments aimed to investigate the system's behavior during transient conditions, focusing on the energy 'cost' associated with adjusting refrigeration system settings to accommodate changes in cooling load demands on the CDU, such as increases or decreases in load.

The preceding data was integrated into an optimization model developed as part of this project's research activities. This model identifies the optimal strategy for adjusting refrigeration system settings to minimize energy consumption while maintaining the required temperature in all mini-containers, subject to various constraints imposed by the refrigeration system and the specific needs of the products stored in the mini-containers. The results showed that the application of this two-step optimization strategy can render significant savings in energy use, paving the way for the use of battery-operated systems.

The results demonstrated that implementing this two-step optimization strategy can yield substantial energy savings, creating a viable path forward for the adoption of battery-operated systems and further reducing the environmental footprint of the CDU.

Phase II of the project will concentrate on developing an intelligent system that leverages the insights gained from the research performed in Phase I to optimally respond to highly variable loads. This system will utilize historical and predictive data to dynamically adjust the CDU's capacity in real-time, ensuring precise matching with expected fluctuating demands.
